Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 01:23AM MaiTai wrote: Hi All, I felt a little on the outside until this thread. I too had neo-chemo (4 AC + 12 TAXOL + year of herceptin). I had the surgery 3-4 weeks after ending chemo and was still on herceptin. BMX found complete pathological response. There was only a tiny spot of DCIS left. When I get anxious it is comforting to know that I am regarded as CPR. I wish I had done the sentinel operation before the chemo though. I saw 2 oncs. One suggested I did the sentinel op. first, then chemo and then the operation. The second onc + the BS did not recommend two surgical procedures. I opted to agree. Now I wish I hadn't. I think it might have given me more peace to know I was node negative even before the chemo. And if I wasn't I would have known I needed radiation. Which I didn't get because after chemo I was NED. Well, nothing to do now! It is a loop I choose to focus on the positive side of the list and I have another con. to add to the list: If your tumor does not respond well to the chemo, it takes more time until it is out of your body. It is also a risk.
Posts.Title: neoadjuvant chemotherapy and staging ReadingMama Shari0707

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2011 01:16AM - edited Nov 1, 2011 01:19AM by MaiTai Hi, I also had AC and then taxol dose dense both of them. Also managed to work full time all through out. SE were mild, especially fatigue but could not sleep very well. I had my first treatment on my anniversary and instead of treating the red A as a devil, I imagined it as a celebration red baloon and the start of getting well and rid of the cancer. I finished chemo 2 years ago. No heart problems. As many of the ladies here, I go for the aggressive- kick ass approach! Hope chemo goes as easy as possible for you! Oh and I forgot - YES to the EMEND!!
Posts.Title: Red devil or not? Teakay sarasowise

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2011 05:25AM MaiTai wrote: Hi, I worked all through chemo. I feel as if instead of me keeping the routine, the routine "kept" me. I'm a buyer for a retail company and of course could not travel abroad but except that part I went on as usual. The AC was a little tougher. I used to stay home for 2 days after treatment. The 12 taxol + herceptin were easier. I got the denser dose (once every week) and only missed the day of the treatment. I was a little more tired and worked only around 8 hour days, but felt focused and had good outcomes(yay!). I had a little chemo brain so I wrote every thing down and did not try to rely on my memory as I usually do. Everyone at work was very supportive, and I was very lucky. Good Luck to you!! It will be over before you know it.
Posts.Title: Poll: How many ladies worked through Chemo? Chrys23 Chrys23
Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 08:08AM - edited Apr 28, 2011 08:11AM by MaiTai Hi, I was 40 when diagnosed. Very similar to what you went through. Mamo on February 09 only detected microcalcifications. The doctor believed it to be benign and I was supposed to get checked again 12 months later. 3 months later I felt a lump on the right breast. It turned out IDC and multi focal (2 tumors with DCIS between them). I decided on a BMX too. I am not BRCA positive but I felt that I could not trust the Mammo and didn't want to obsess about the other breast. I had the BMX and immediaterecon  with alloderm January 2010. All in one procedure. For me it was the best decision. My daughter was 7 at the time. I worked through chemo but the surgery made me stay put for a month. The first 2 weeks I had the drains in. This was the hardest to manage and most uncomfortable. For the first 2 weeks I needed help to get up from the bed. I needed my DH for that. All the rest I could manage alone (bathing and such). My friends cooked for me, so I just had to heat it. Make sure you have comfortable clothes with front buttons. It is much easier to put on and take off. Especially if you still have drains. I had a hard time driving. Only after a month I was able to do it. I'm more than year away from the surgery and I feel really good. No movement problems or limitations. The recon is really nice. I just want to have my tattoos. I decided on not to recon the nips. My daughter accepted every thing very easily. I believe in open communication and believe that if she has the information and how I feel about it, it is much easy for her to deal with things. She asked to see the scars. She called the smiling boobs I haven't read the whole thread so maybe I'm just repeating what others have advised. I am here if you think I can help. Good Luck!
Posts.Title: I'm 39 with breast cancer, need advice mommyrnx2 waltersmith

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 05:51AM MaiTai wrote: Hi all, I'm now a year after finishing chemo. finished with herceptin last August. I have to have dental work done, but my onc is not pushing for zometa. I'm sure it will be more than a year when I finish at the dentist and I'm only ER+ (PR-), which I think makes me a little less sensitive to hormonal treatment. I'm afraid of SE especialy the harm it can do to the jaw. Any PR- getting the zometa? sgreenarch - Funny story about the zomera. greetings from TA
